column1: Morelia (Spanish pronunciation: [moˈɾelja]; from 1545 to 1828 known as Valladolid) is a city and municipality in the north central part of the state of Michoacán in central Mexico. The city is in the Guayangareo Valley and is the capital and largest city of the state. The main pre-Hispanic cultures here were the Purépecha and the Matlatzinca
column2: but no major cities were founded in the valley during this time. The Spanish took control of the area in the 1520s. The Spanish under Viceroy Antonio de Mendoza founded a settlement here in 1541 with the name of Valladolid
column3: which became rival to the nearby city of Pátzcuaro for dominance in Michoacán. In 1580
column4: this rivalry ended in Valladolid's favor and it became the capital of the colonial province. After the Mexican War of Independence
column5: the city was renamed Morelia in honor of José María Morelos
column6: who hailed from the city. In 1991
column7: the city was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site for its well-preserved colonial buildings and layout of the historic center.

column1: == History ==

Human settlements in the Guayangareo Valley in which Morelia is located have been dated back as far as the 7th century.  Artifacts found here have shown Teotihuacán culture influence on early cultures in this area. In the 12th century
column2: the Purépecha arrived in the valley. They dominated it politically for the rest of the pre-Hispanic period but did not build any major settlements here. Between the 12th and the 15th century
column3: Matlatzincas moved into the area with permission of the Purépechas
column4: who were based around nearby Pátzcuaro Lake. The main Matlatzinca settlement was where Júarez Plaza in the city is today.The Spanish pushed into the Guayangareo Valley between 1525 and 1526
column5: headed by Gonzalo Gómez. In the 1530s
column6: the area was evangelized by Franciscans such as Juan de San Miguel and Antonio de Lisboa.What would become the city of Morelia was founded by Viceroy Antonio de Mendoza and a number of encomenderos in 1541
column7: who first named it Nueva Ciudad de Mechuacan (New City of Michoacán). The newly founded settlement grew quickly
column8: prompting Vasco de Quiroga to go to Spain and procure for rival settlement Pátzcuaro the title of city and a seal
column9: to prevent “new city” from becoming the capital of Michoacán. The action also required that the new settlement change its name to Guayangareo. In 1545
column10: Guayangareo gained city status from Charles V in 1545 with the name of Valladolid
column11: after the hometown of Antonio de Mendoza. This was part of a power struggle between Antonio de Mendoza and Vasco de Quiroga over the province of Michoacán. During Quiroga's lifetime
column12: he managed to keep political and ecclesiastical power in Pátzcuaro despite the viceroy's and encomenderos’ objections. However
column14: both political and religious authority (Episcopal see) had been transferred to the city of Valladolid
column15: moving the College of San Nicolás
column16: which Vasco founded and laying the groundwork for establishing a new cathedral for the province.The 17th century saw growth for Valladolid
column17: with the construction of the cathedral and aqueduct. The cathedral was begun in 1640 (finished in 1744) and the aqueduct in 1657. Both of these structures would later be worked on in the 18th century by Master Architect of Valladolid
column19: many of the city's large churches and monasteries were established
column20: such as the monasteries of San Francisco
column22: El Carmen and La Merced as well as the convents of Las Rosas
column23: Las Monjas and Capuchinas. Churches include La Compañía
column25: but the most important structure built during this time period was the cathedral. The location of this cathedral defined the composition and development of the city from then on.At the end of the colonial period
column26: Valladolid was a small city with about 20
column27: 000 inhabitants. It was also an educational center with four important schools such as the College of San Nicolás. These schools would turn out scholars such as Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla and José María Morelos y Pavón
column28: who were sympathetic to the new republican ideas coming out of post-revolution France and United States. Demonstrations against Spanish rule had been occurring in the town in 1809
column29: culminating in the Conspiracy of 1809. This plot was discovered
column30: with the main conspirators were arrested and sent to other parts of New Spain
column31: which helped to spread republican ideas.One year later
column32: after forming his army in Guanajuato state
column33: Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla arrived and took over the city
column34: proclaiming the end of slavery in Mexico. The city was taken back by royalist forces soon after. Morelos came here to try and dislodge the royalists but was defeated by Agustín de Iturbide. Another prominent figure in the war
column35: Mariano Matamoros was shot by firing squad on the city's main square in 1814. The city remained in royalist hands until 1821
column38: and Vicente Guerrero entered the city with the Trigarante Army.In 1828
column39: the newly created state of Michoacán changed the name of the city from Valladolid to Morelia
column40: in honor of José María Morelos y Pavón. This is the official name it retains today
column41: although its Purépecha name remains Uaianarhio and has had nicknames such as City of Pink (Cantera) Stone
column44: The Garden of New Spain and religiously as Morelia of the Sacred Heart of Jesus. The city became a municipality in 1831.The later 19th century is marked by struggles between liberal and conservatives forces in Mexico. During the Revolution of Ayutla
column45: the city was taken by rebel forces under Epitacio Huerta and General García Pueblita
column46: but was taken back in 1855 by forces under Antonio López de Santa Anna. Rebels attacked Santa Anna's troops again a year later. French troops imposing imperial rule entered the city in 1863
column47: with the republican forces moving capital of Michoacán to Uruapan while conservative families in Morelia pledged support for emperor Maximilian I
column48: who then visited the city. In 1867
column49: the city is taken by republican general Nicolás de Régules and the capital of Michoacán returned to Morelia.  In 1869
column50: during a rebellion against Benito Juárez’s government
column51: General Epitacio Huerta attacked government positions in the city but were beaten back by forces under Mariano Escobedo.

column1: The first factories were opened in the city between 1868 and 1870
column2: along with the first telegraph line. The railroad followed in 1883
column3: as well as street cars.In 1910
column4: celebrations are held for the centennial of Independence but tensions are high in the city due to the shortage of grain and the continuation of President Porfirio Diaz in power. One year later
column5: revolutionaries loyal to Francisco I. Madero are welcomed into the city. In 1914
column6: the capital was moved from Morelia to the city of Tacámbaro. The city was then taken by forces under General Sánchez in the same year
column7: and by forces loyal to Francisco Villa in 1915.In 1920
column8: the Palace of the State Government was briefly taken over by farm workers and others from all over the state. Isaac Arriaga is assassinated here in 1921. The city is attacked again by rebels calling themselves “Delahuertistas” in 1924. The fight mostly occurs in the main plaza with the city defended by General Lopez
column9: Garcia and Avila Camacho.During the 1960s the street vendors were removed from the historic center of the city
column10: and palm trees that lined the Avenida Madero
column13: there was a student revolt at the state university which was put down by the army.The 1970s and 1980s are marked by construction including the Periferico bypass ring around the city. During the 1980s
column15: exacerbated by falling water tables from groundwater pumping is noticed. This problem is similar to problems faced by other cities on the Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt such as Querétaro and Mexico City.In 1991
column16: the city was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site due to its well-preserved colonial architecture. In 2001
column17: street vendors were moved again from the historic center to make the area more tourist-friendly. Traffic was rerouted from here as well with the construction of new bypasses. In 2006 and 2007
column18: many of the plazas and gardens in the historic center were remodeled.In 2008
column19: eight people were killed in a grenade attack.

column2: the Morelia metropolitan area was tentatively established as consisting of the municipalities of Zinapécuaro

column4: Charo

column1: == Geography ==
=== Climate ===
Under the Köppen climate classification
column2: Morelia has a subtropical highland climate (Cwb)
column3: with warm-to-hot days and cool nights year round due to its high elevation. Most precipitation falls during the summer rainy season. Average monthly temperatures are between 14 and 22 °C (57 and 72 °F)
column4: with maximum temperatures of 38.3 °C (100.9 °F) in the summer of 1998 and the lowest temperature of −5.2 °C (22.6 °F) in January 1985.

column1: == Government ==
== Notable sites ==
Almost all of Morelia's notable sites lie in its historic center
column2: due to its history. This historic center is roughly equivalent to the original layout of the city when it was founded in 1541
column3: and most of this layout has survived intact to the present day. Anticipating growth
column4: this original layout had very wide streets and plazas for the time
column5: with streets systematically arranged to allow for elongation. The streets are systematically laid out
column7: with most having gentle curves designed into them. Most of the grandest structures were completed during the 18th century
column8: including the facade and bell towers of the cathedral
column9: the Colegio Seminario (today the State Government Palace)
column10: La Alhóndiga (today part of the Palace of Justice) and numerous private mansions. During the same time period
column11: infrastructure such as the city's aqueduct and various plaza fountains were constructed. The Mexican federal government lists 1
column12: 113 buildings built from the 16th to the 20th century as having historical value. The buildings encompass the various architectural styles that have been fashionable in Mexico
column13: but nearly all are built of pink cantera stone
column14: which gives the city a unified appearance. Several measures were taken in the 20th century to preserve this part of the city. In 1956
column15: the city enacted regulations to preserve the historic center's colonial buildings. In 1990
column16: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari issued a decree making the historic center of Morelia a national historic monument. In 1991
column17: the same area was declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO
column18: which covers 200 of the area's historic buildings.

column1: The heart of the historic center is the cathedral and its surrounding plazas: the Plaza de Armas
column2: also known as the Plaza de los Mártires
column3: the Juárez Plaza and the Melchor Ocampo Plaza.  The largest plaza is the Plaza de Armas
column4: which has been remodeled several times since it was designed in the 16th century. It has been renamed several times as well
column5: from “de la Constitución
column6: ” “de la República” to the current official name of “de los Mártires” but popularly it retains the name of “Plaza de Armas.” The alternate name
column7: Plaza de los Mártires (Plaza of the Martyrs) is in honor of people like Mariano Matamoros
column8: Guadalupe el Salto and others who were executed here during the Mexican War of Independence and later in 1830 during political unrest. The plaza is surrounded by portals
column9: and colonial era buildings such as the Banca Promex
column11: the Juan de Dios Gomez House and the old town hall
column12: also called the Michelena House. Until the late 19th century
column13: a monument to Morelos had been here
column14: but this was removed along with the fountain and replaced by a kiosk that was brought from London and remains to this day. The last remodeling of the plaza occurred in the mid 20th century under the direction of architect and painter Juan O'Gorman. The Melchor Ocampo Plaza was originally named “Plaza de la Paz.” In the late 19th century
column15: this plaza was remodeled and a monument to Ocampo sculpted by Primitivo Miranda was placed here. Another statue by Miranda
column16: this one of Jose Maria Morelos y Pavon was placed in the small plaza on the west side of the cathedral and named the Morelos Plaza.

column1: The first church on the Cathedral site was built in 1577
column2: which was a modest structure of adobe and wood. Many years later
column3: this structure would be almost completely destroyed by a fire. Originally
column4: the Cathedral of Michoacán was in Pátzcuaro in a church that now is the Basilica of Nuestra Señora de la Salud. When cathedral status was moved from there to Valladolid in 1580
column5: the city became the civil
column6: religious and cultural capital of the territory. In 1660
column8: placed the first stone of the new cathedral
column9: which was designed by Vicenzo Baroccio. Of the major churches of the early colonial period
column10: only this and the Mexico City Cathedral do not face west
column11: as was customary. The Cathedral of Michoacán is also unique in that it is dedicated to the Transfiguration of Jesus
column12: rather than some form of the Virgin Mary. The cathedral was consecrated in 1705
column13: even though it was not yet finished. The facade as a relief of the transfiguration of Christ and the east nave is dedicated to the sheepherders and Wise Men of the Nativity. Built of pink cantera stone
column14: the cathedral's two 60-meter-high (200 ft) towers still dominate the skyline of the city
column15: and are the second tallest Baroque towers in Mexico.The cathedral's official name is Cathedral of the Divine Savior of Morelia. Since it was built over the 17th and 18th century
column17: Herreresque and Baroque architecture can be seen in the building. The facade of the cathedral is mostly decorated in pilasters rather than columns and relieves rather than sculptures. There are more than two hundred pilasters but no columns
column18: the only church built this way during the colonial period.Inside
column19: there are a number of elements that stand out. The baptismal font was made of silver in the 19th century and was used to baptize Mexico's first emperor
column20: Agustín de Iturbide. A three-meter-tall (9.8 ft) monstrance made of pure silver adorns the main altar and is unique in that it can be disassembled and reassembled. Also on the altar is a 16th-century cornstalk paste image of the Señor de la Sacristía (Lord of the Sacristy)
column21: whose gold crown was a gift from Philip II of Spain. A newer addition is the organ from Germany
column23: 600 pipes and is one of the largest in Latin America. On Saturdays at 8:45 pm the cathedral sponsors a sound-and-light show.In front of the cathedral is the old Seminario Tridentino de San Pedro
column24: one of the educational institutions of the colonial city. Today it is the Palace of the State Government. It was constructed by Thomás de Huerta in the latter 18th century. The school had graduates such as José María Morelos and Melchor Ocampo. The facade is mostly the original
column25: with only the seal of Mexico added in the mid 19th century
column26: when this building was converted for use as the home of the Michoacán state government. Inside are three courtyards with the walls of the first courtyard covered in murals done by Alfredo Zalce in the 1960s.

column1: Traslado de las Monjas in the musueumThe Casa de la Cultura is also the home of the Instituto Michoacano de Cultura (Michoacan Institute of Culture) and the State Secretary of Culture. It is in the former monastery of Nuestra Señora del Carmen Descalzo
column2: which was established in 1593. The church building was probably finished in 1619
column3: the date inscribed on the south portal
column4: but monastery construction continued into the 17th century. In the 19th century
column5: the Reform Laws expropriated the cloisters and living quarters but left the church to its religious function
column6: which continues to this day. After expropriation
column7: the monastery area was first used as the home of the Primer Cuerpo de Caballería del Estado (First Cavalry Corps of the State). Over time the church fell into disrepair but was restored in the 1940s. The rest of the complex was restored and converted to its present function starting in 1977.The Orquidario of Morelia is an orchid museum which houses approximately 3
column8: 400 species of the flower. The botanical garden consists of three greenhouses with some outside space. The museum is managed by SEMARNAT as part of a program to preserve wild species. The botanical garden has a surface area of over 990 meters2 and was founded in 1980.The Museo Regional Michoacano (Regional Museum of Michoacán) was founded in 1886 and its design was heavily influenced by French ideas of museum design of the time. It is housed in a building that belonged to Emperor Maximilian I
column9: and is of ornate Baroque design. Most of the exhibits are about the history of the region with rooms dedicated to pre-Hispanic artifacts and colonial art. One noted piece is the painting called “Traslado de las Monjas” which is considered to be the finest work produced in Michoacán during the colonial period. Other important works include the original volume of the Voyage de Humboldt et Bonpland
column10: edited in Paris in 1807 and the murals done by Alfredo Zalce
column11: Federico Cantú and Grace Greenwood. There are also interactive exhibits on the origins of the earth and life. The museum also has conference rooms
column12: a library and a reading room.

column1: The Museo del Estado (The State Museum) is dedicated to the state's past and present. It was opened in 1986 and divided into three sections – archeology
column2: history and ethnology of the state. There is also an exhibit of the old Mier Pharmacy with its equipment from 1868. The museum is a mansion dating from the 18th century.The Museo de Arte Colonial (Museum of Colonial Art) holds a collection of documents
column3: old books
column4: religious ornaments and maps from the colonial period. Its main attraction is its collection of more than 100 figures of Christ done in cornstalk paste. These figures were created by indigenous artists
column5: starting under the direction of Vasco de Quiroga
column6: between the 16th and 19th centuries. There are also paintings done by Miguel Cabrera and José Padilla from the 18th century. The museum is in an old Baroque residence from the 18th century. Prior to the building's use as a museum
column7: it was the site of the first official government press in the state
column8: founded in 1821.The Casa Museum José María Morelos y Pavón (José María Morelos y Pavón House Museum) contains a collection of items from the colonial and early independence periods of Mexico's history
column9: including articles that belonged to Morelos himself. Morelos bought the house in 1802
column10: but did not live there much
column11: especially in the years just before and during the Mexican War of Independence because of his involvement with the movement. In 1933
column12: the house was declared a national monument and in 1939 became the property of INAH to be converted into this museum. Later
column13: the building underwent another round of restoration work and was re-inaugurated in 1991. The lower level is mostly dedicated to Morelos with the rooms on the upper level dedicated to the war in general. The museum is also the archive of the Bishopric of Michoacán and contains documents from the 16th to the 20th century.

column1: The Casa Natal de Morelos (Morelos’ Birthplace) is the house where José María Morelos y Pavón was born in 1765. The building is a large mansion with a Neoclassic facade and a Baroque interior. In 1888
column2: the original building was destroyed to build a farmhouse. This is the building that has been restored and turned into a museum in 1964
column3: for the coming bicentennial of Morelos’ birth. The museum contains documents and belongings of Morelos including ones he signed
column4: money he had coined
column5: paintings and a large library.The Museo de la Máscara (Mask Museum) presents two different mask collections
column6: totaling more than 165 examples from cultures in twenty Mexican states. It is located in the Casa de Artesanias de Morelia (Handcraft House of Morelia).The Museo de Arte Contemporáneo Alfredo Zalce (Alfredo Zalce Museum of Contemporary Art) mostly contains works done by Alfredo Zalce and Efraín Vargas
column7: both renowned Michoacán painters. It also holds temporary exhibits by Mexican and international artists.The Plaza Monumental de Morelia was established in 1951
column8: which was destined exclusively for bullfights. Nowadays
column11: and weddings.The city Aqueduct was first documented in the year 1549. As it was uses to navigate fresh water to the required destination that the people could get it from. The water system was made of used wood from canoes in the area to create the base structure during its construction. As years passed with the usability of the aqueduct constantly changing
column12: there was an incident that occurred in the year 1784. The incident was that part of the Morelia aqueduct foundation collapsed
column13: leaving hundreds without access to the water. On October 21
column15: a concerning documented the reconstruction of the aqueduct
column16: a man named Fray Antonio de San Miguel volunteered make a plan of the reconstruction of the structure. With Fray Antonio plans they completely reconstructed the arches and added fixtures to fix up the previous damages. As the damages were completed the aqueduct was used until it stopped functioning in the year 1910
column17: it still remains in standing to this day. The whole Aqueduct structure consisted of 253 arches (some have collapsed during the years)

column1: == Festivals ==
The Festival Internacional de Música de Morelia is an annual event that was begun in 1988 by Bernal Jiménez
column2: who had the dream of making Morelia the “Salzburg of Americas”. The festival consists of more than forty concerts with over 500 artists participating. It has become the largest music festival in Morelia
column3: with private and government sponsors
column4: esp. CONACULTA. Concerts include those by chamber orquestras
column5: choirs
column7: trios and soloists such as pianist Joanna MacGregor and the Britten Symphony. Each year
column8: a different country is the “special guest
column9: ” which in 2009 was the United Kingdom. In that year
column10: some of the participants included the London Symphony Orchestra
column13: the Coro Nova Scholla Gregoriana Di Verona of Italy
column14: and violinist Tanya Anisimova from Russia. Participants from Mexico included the National Symphonic Orchestra
column15: the Orquesta Sinfónica de Minería and flautist Horacio Franco.The International Summer Opera Festival of Morelia (ISOFOM) started in 2017 and has attracted thousands of audience members to its opera galas and concerts. Students come from all over the world to study with the renowned faculty and experience the life in Morelia for three weeks each June. In 2019
column16: the festival presents its first full-length opera Falstaff by Verdi
column18: as well as a Gala evening in the Palacio Clavijero. The mission of ISOFOM is to bring young up-and-coming performers of opera to the Michoacan audiences and share with them that special art form in landmark locations all across Morelia

column1: The Festival Internacional de Cine de Morelia was begun in 2003
column2: and is mostly dedicated to Mexican cinema
column3: showcasing up-and-coming directors and productions. The majority of activities take place in the Cinépolis Morelia Centro
column4: but also includes other theaters
column5: auditoriums and public plazas.

column1: Morelia is the site of the annual Zapata Vive Morelia Festival
column2: which celebrates the life of Emiliano Zapata with cultural and political activities. The purpose of the event is to promote exhibitions by artistic
column3: cultural and social organizations from the state of Michoacán and other parts of the country. Events are spread out over several days and include ones such as concerts
column4: round tables and information sessions. The event encourages those organizations who work with the lower social classes and are politically left to participate.The Festival de Escala is an annual event dedicated to promoting rock climbing in the municipality at places such as El Paredón de la Noria
column5: just south of the city proper.A popular festival that features a 3-day Salsa competition in the heart of Morelia is called "SalsaMich". Typically held in March
column6: the festival brings Salsa dancers from all across the country to Morelia to compete for prizes.

column1: == Education ==
During the colonial period the city had four major educational institutions
column2: the Colegio Seminario Tridentino
column3: the Colegio de San Nicolás
column4: the Colegio de los Jesuitas and the Colegio de las Rosas.

column1: The state university
column2: the Universidad Michoacana de San Nicolás de Hidalgo
column3: is the oldest university in the Americas
column4: which has its origins in the college founded in 1540 by Vasco de Quiroga in Pátzcuaro
column5: the Colegio de San Nicolás Obispo. This school was founded to train priests and missionaries for work in Michoacán. The school gained a royal seal and patronage in 1543. In 1566
column6: colonial religious authorities took over the school and in 1574
column7: academics here were under the jurisdiction of the Jesuits. With the episcopal seat changed to Valladolid
column8: the school moved also in 1580 and was fused with the already existing Colegio de San Miguel Guayangareo. The school was reformed in the 17th century and its curriculum was redesigned in the 18th to include courses in philosophy
column10: civil law and other subjects.  At the beginning the 19th century
column11: the school became one of New Spain's main centers of learning and academia
column12: producing scholars such as a Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla
column15: José María Izazaga and Ignacio López Rayón
column16: most of whom would have a role in the upcoming Mexican War of Independence. The school closed during the war but was reopened in 1847 with the name Primitivo y Nacional Colegio de San Nicolás de Hidalgo
column17: focusing more on secular studies such as chemistry
column21: etc. based on the European university model.

column1: After the Mexican Revolution
column2: the school was reorganized and renamed again to the Universidad Michocana de San Nicolás de Hidalgo in 1917
column3: which consolidated a number of other schools and disciplines into the new organization.Nowadays
column4: the Universidad Michoacana de San Nicolás de Hidalgo is the most important university in the state of Michoacán. It has been rated also as one of the Top 10 best public universities in Mexico. The university has recently expanded to other smaller cities in the state other than Morelia
column5: such as Uruapan

column1: Other universities in the city include Instituto Tecnológico de Morelia (ITM)
column2: Universidad Tecnológica de Morelia (UTM)
column3: Instituto Michoacano de Ciencias de la Educación
column4: Centro de Investigación y Desarrollo del Estado de Michoacán (CIDEM)
column5: the Morelia Campus of the National Autonomous University of Mexico
column6: Instituo de Estudios Superiores de la Comunicación (IESCAC)
column12: Instituto Tecnológico y de Estudios Superiores de Monterrey- Campus Morelia ITESM
column13: Universidad Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz and many other different private universities.

column1: == Sports ==
Morelia is represented by their soccer team
column2: Monarcas Morelia
column3: in the Liga MX.

column1: Monarcas Morelia was founded in 1950 on a field outside the city where a monument to Lázaro Cárdenas is now located. The team's original name was Club Deportivo Morelia and was owned by Eucuario Gómez. The club's colors are the city's flag colors red and yellow because Morelia is known to be the most Spanish city in Mexico.
was nicknamed “Amarillo”(Yellow) During the 1956–57 season
column2: when the club won the right to play in the 1st division in which they played in their first tournament for the Copa México against Club América.

column1: The club descended into the 2nd division again in 1968 and experienced tough times during the early 70s. By the end of the 1973–74 season the team was completely restructured by 32 Morelia Businessmen who acquired the team. After 13 years in the 2nd division
column2: the team finally returned to 1st division play in 1981 and by the mid-1980s was competitive and reaching the Liguilla (playoffs) regularly.

column1: Following many years of playing at Estadio Venustiano Carranza
column2: the completion of Estadio Morelos in 1989 gave the team a new home. In 1996
column3: the team was acquired by TV Azteca and the name Monarcas (Monarchs) Morelia was adopted in 1999 because of the three Spanish Monarchs shown in the flag of Morelia. The team won its first championship during the Invierno 2000 season and by mid-decade
column4: was playing in international competition such as the Copa Libertadores and the Liga de Campeones de la CONACACAF (CONCACAF Champions League). The team's latest success came during the 2010 North American SuperLiga tournament
column5: which Monarcas won over the New England Revolution on September 1

column1: The team closed the Apertura 2010 tournament of the Primera División de México (Mexico's 1st division)
column2: failing to make the "liguilla".

column1: == Transportation ==
Morelia is three or four hours from Mexico City via the Atlacomulco-Maravatío-Morelia highway and is connected by highways to the states of Mexico
column2: Querétaro
column3: Guanajuato and Jalisco. It is connected to the Michoacán coast via highway 200 that passes through Uruapan to the port of Lázaro Cárdenas. General Francisco Mujica International Airport or Morelia International Airport (IATA: MLM
column4: ICAO: MMMM) is an international airport at Morelia
column5: Michoacán
column6: Mexico. The airport handles both domestic and international flights
column14: Tijuana and several destinations in the United States. The airport is named after a former governor of the state of Michoacán.

column1: == The municipality ==
As the municipal seat
column2: Morelia is the governing authority of 423 other communities
column3: almost all of which are small communities of between three and 1
column4: 000 people
column5: with 89% of the municipality's population of 684
column6: 145 people within the city itself. The municipality covers a territory of 1
column7: 199.02 square kilometres (462.94 sq mi) and borders the municipalities of Tarímbaro
column16: Tzintzuntzan and Quiroga.Much of the municipality is in the Guayangareo Valley between two rivers: the El Grande and the El Chiquito. Guayangareo means "large hill with a flat side." The municipality's territory is rugged and dominated by peaks such as Punhuato
column17: El Zapote and the Otzumatlán mountain range
column18: with the highest peak being Quinceo with an elevation of 2
column20: 144 ft). The municipality belongs to the Lerma-Santiago river hydraulic region
column21: with the main rivers being the El Grande and the El Chiquito. There are a number of streams including the Zarza and Pitaya. The most important dam here is Cointzio
column22: with other smaller ones being Umécuaro

column1: Vegetation outside the city varies based on elevation and the type of soil. Mountainous areas are mostly covered in conifers while lower and drier areas have trees such as mesquite. To the south of the city is the Lázaro Cárdenas Forest
column2: which is an ecological reserve. Animal life mostly consists of small mammals
column3: with coyotes being the largest
column4: birds of prey and some reptiles.The growth of the city of Morelia is having a negative impact on the surrounding forested area. This is particularly problematic in the area north of the city
column5: which belongs to the Lake Cuitzeo basin
column6: and is a main recharge area for the city's aquifer. The forested areas around the city are also important for the city's air quality and as a breeding place for pollinating insects needed for agriculture. UNAM has been documenting the species in these forests with the aim of getting them declared as biological reserves.One industrial area is the Ciudad Industrial de Morelia
column7: which mostly houses small and medium-sized enterprises. Some of the products manufactured here include cooking oil
column11: bottling and candies. Tourism is a rising component of the economy
column12: taking advantage of area's colonial heritage
column14: natural areas and archeological zones such as Santa María de Guido in the city
column15: Barranca de los Lobos in Teremendo
column16: Nahuatl Sanctuary and Catrina in Capula. However
column17: it has not been developed sufficiently to be a major contributor. Tourism accounts for the main economic activity in Morelia. Morelia contains many ecological areas
column19: which attracts majority of tourists and local residents. Unfortunately
column20: due to Mexico's rising crime in drug trafficking within the cartels
column21: this can provide a grave disincentive in the tourism sector for Morelia.According to Standard & Poor's report for November 2009
column22: the government of Morelia maintains an adequate development budget
column23: backed by relatively high income and low debt. It is rated on a national scale for Mexico as A+. The economy is projected to be stable with the government keeping control of expenses.
